citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
During the inspection, it was noted that ten animals had died without veterinary care and/or of unknown causes since the
last inspection on 12-10-24. The dead animals included one capybara (1-03-25), one cape porcupine (1-8-25), one zebu
(3-6-25), one hairless guinea pig (1-24-25), four goats (12-30-24, 1-5-25, 2 on 1-14-25), one common marmoset (1-29-
25), and one rhea (12-20-24). The licensee reported that the capybara had died giving birth and the rest of the listed
animals had been found dead in the morning. No veterinary exams or necropsies were performed to determine cause of
death. No follow-up veterinary care or diagnostics were reported for any cohoused animals.
The death of ten animals in three months not under veterinary care prior to their death, or evaluation after their deaths,
indicates that there is no protocol in place to determine cause of death. Deaths of unknown cause may indicate an
underlining herd health or other husbandry problem.
A facility must have a program of veterinary care in place that uses appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose,
and treat diseases and injuries.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A female cow housed with the pen with 4 cattle, one sheep and ten goats had a right rear hoof that was misshaped and
overgrown. The tips of both digits on the right rear hoof were pointed upwards. The cow walks with an abnormal gait, was
walking very slowly and appeared to be trying to keep weight off the right rear foot.
Overgrown hooves can lead to an abnormal gait and potential bone changes that can become chronically painful.
Each exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include daily observation of all
animals to assess their health and well-being. Daily observation of animals may be accomplished by someone other than
the attending veterinarian provided that a mechanism of direct and frequent communication with the attending veterinarian
is accomplished so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is
conveyed to the attending veterinarian.

There was a large accumulation of fecal material and contaminated hay surrounding the hay feeder in the enclosure
housing, one sheep, four domestic cattle and ten goats.
Lack of cleaning of primary enclosures can lead to parasite infestation and other diseases.
Excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals
contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors.

There is one male and one female ostrich being housed together. The female ostrich has feather loss on nearly her entire
back and her wings were drooping down by her sides. The facility representative reported that this was due to breeding
behavior by the male.
Feather loss can lead to temperature stress and poor well-being. Excessive breeding behavior can cause injury to birds.
Birds may not be housed with other animals, including members of their own species, unless they are compatible, do not
prevent access to food, water, or shelter by individual animals, and are not known to be hazardous to the health and well-
being of each other. Compatibility must be determined in accordance with generally accepted professional practices and
by actual observations to ensure that the birds are, in fact, compatible.
To be corrected by March 14th, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Bryan Voetberg, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Critical Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
During the inspection, it was noted that ten animals had died without veterinary care and/or of unknown causes since the 
last inspection on 12-10-24. The dead animals included one capybara (1-03-25), one cape porcupine (1-8-25), one zebu 
(3-6-25), one hairless guinea pig (1-24-25), four goats (12-30-24, 1-5-25, 2 on 1-14-25), one common marmoset (1-29-
25), and one rhea (12-20-24). The licensee reported that the capybara had died giving birth and the rest of the listed 
animals had been found dead in the morning. No veterinary exams or necropsies were performed to determine cause of 
death. No follow-up veterinary care or diagnostics were reported for any cohoused animals.  
The death of ten animals in three months not under veterinary care prior to their death, or evaluation after their deaths, 
indicates that there is no protocol in place to determine cause of death. Deaths of unknown cause may indicate an 
underlining herd health or other husbandry problem.  
A facility must have a program of veterinary care in place that uses appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, 
and treat diseases and injuries. 
2.40(b)(3)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A female cow housed with the pen with 4 cattle, one sheep and ten goats had a right rear hoof that was misshaped and 
overgrown. The tips of both digits on the right rear hoof were pointed upwards. The cow walks with an abnormal gait, was 
walking very slowly and appeared to be trying to keep weight off the right rear foot. 
Overgrown hooves can lead to an abnormal gait and potential bone changes that can become chronically painful. 
Each exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include daily observation of all

the attending veterinarian provided that a mechanism of direct and frequent communication with the attending veterinarian 
is accomplished so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is 
conveyed to the attending veterinarian. 
3.131(a)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
There was a large accumulation of fecal material and contaminated hay surrounding the hay feeder in the enclosure 
housing, one sheep, four domestic cattle and ten goats.

Lack of cleaning of primary enclosures can lead to parasite infestation and other diseases. 
Excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals 
contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. 
3.160(b) 
   
Compatibility and separation 
There is one male and one female ostrich being housed together. The female ostrich has feather loss on nearly her entire 
back and her wings were drooping down by her sides. The facility representative reported that this was due to breeding 
behavior by the male. 
Feather loss can lead to temperature stress and poor well-being. Excessive breeding behavior can cause injury to birds.  
Birds may not be housed with other animals, including members of their own species, unless they are compatible, do not 
prevent access to food, water, or shelter by individual animals, and are not known to be hazardous to the health and well-
being of each other. Compatibility must be determined in accordance with generally accepted professional practices and 
by actual observations to ensure that the birds are, in fact, compatible.  
To be corrected by March 14th, 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Bryan Voetberg, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
